Award.AwardTitle: International Conference: Frontiers in Systems and Synthetic Biology in Atlanta, Georgia March 20-24, 2013

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The hallmark of systems biology is often presented as the pursuit of understanding how biological systems function. Once such understanding is gained, it can be utilized to the manipulation and optimization of existing systems toward worthwhile goals or toward the creation of entirely new systems within the nascent field of synthetic biology. Interestingly, the meaning of "understanding biological systems" varies quite widely among the practitioners of systems biology. For some, it is the confirmation that mathematical representations of components and processes, when merged into a larger model, fit together and collectively yield responses similar to those observed in actuality. If so, one assumes that further predictions with the model are reasonably reliable as well. In interesting cases, the merging of processes has the potential of leading to new, emerging properties. Others define as the desirable goal a collection of very accurate simulation systems, including complete cell simulators. Like a flight simulator that is used for pilot training, a biological systems simulator could mimic simple, frequently encountered situations, as well as very rare and complex emergencies or outliers, and thereby hone skill and intuition of students and researchers alike. Yet others define "understanding" as the discovery and elucidation of general organizing principles in the form of network motifs or design and operating principles. This interpretation of understanding aims to explain and rationalize why nature uses certain structures and strategies to solve specific tasks, but not alternatives that seem equally reasonable. As one easily imagines, the different goals have been addressed with genuinely different computational methods.

The conference will focus on the interplay between these apparently disparate goals, which clearly address different aspects of the same phenomena. It will facilitate discussions of the different variants, their purposes, and methods, and help the field characterize the role of one in the pursuit of the others. The conference will also encourage presentations on the education of biologists, computational scientists and engineers in the emerging fields of systems and synthetic biology.

Broader Impacts
The conference will be kept relatively small, with an expected enrollment of about 100 participants. This size will be particularly appealing to students and junior faculty, who will have the opportunity to meet leaders in the field face to face. Senior researchers will be invited to present introductory talks, but every effort will be made to assure that junior colleagues and students have a stake in the design of the program and the execution of the conference. To this end, the organizing committee will consist of two senior and three junior faculty, including two members from underserved groups, as well as two students. Students and postdoctoral fellows will be encouraged to participate and present talks and posters and be given, on a competitive basis, conference fee waivers and travel stipends, as far as the budget allows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In March 2013, Georgia Tech hosted an international scientific conference at the interface of biology, computation, mathematical modeling and engineering. The central topic was the emerging field of systems and synthetic biology. Practitioners of this field use modern experiments of molecular biology to assess the multitude of genes, metabolites, proteins, and other classes of molecules in a cell or organism, and combine and analyze the results of these experiments with sophisticated computational, mathematical, and engineering tools. Because both, the necessary methods of data generation and the computational tools of analysis, were not available even two decades ago, the field is still young, its scope is not yet clearly defined, and many of its methods are exploratory, rather than definitively standardized. As a consequence, students and young faculty find it difficult to grasp the complexity of this nascent field.

            Systems biology has two major long-term goals, which at first appear to be very different and indeed almost inconsistent with each other, even though this is not truly the case. The first goal is the generation of very large and complicated computational models that allow the simulation of whole cells or organisms in a fashion reminiscent of a flight simulator. Clearly, such simulations of complicated biological systems would be very powerful and have applications of incredible potential. The second goal of systems biology is the generation of simple, yet crisply focused models that elucidate the deep principles underlying the functionality of biological systems. These principles objectively explain why nature uses certain structures, processes and strategies to solve specific tasks, but not alternatives that at first may seem equally reasonable. It is not difficult to see that this type of discovery requires mathematical methods that are very different from the construction of large simulators.

            In order to facilitate an appreciation of the different goals, concepts and methods within the field, the International Conference: Frontiers in Systems and Synthetic Biology ‘13 invited an interdisciplinary group of experts to deliver plenary presentations. Complementing these presentations, the organizers allowed for a considerable number of contributed talks by experts as well as newcomers. Many students and young investigators attended the conference and presented posters. Furthermore, a diverse panel of experts discussed future trends in the field and answered questions from the audience. Finally, two cognitive scientists led an interactive session on new problem-solving paradigms for teaching a complex topic like systems biology. This session was remendously successful and especially welcomed by younger faculty who are tasked with teaching systems biology to graduate and undergraduate students.

            The conference was attended by over 120 participants, more than half of whom were students and postdoctoral fellows. According to feedback, the conference was a great success, and a similar conference is planned for 2015 in Japan.
